misconfigurations.alert_criteria: DynamoDB tables showing zero read or write activity over 7, 14, or 30+ day lookback period
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Delete the table if no longer required, export data to S3 before deletion if retention needed, implement lifecycle tagging and ownership metadata to prevent future orphaned storage
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: This issue occurs when a DynamoDB table continues to accumulate storage charges despite having no active workload accessing it. Tables often become orphaned after project completion, feature retirement, or data migration elsewhere. They represent a cost liability without providing functional value. Detection requires: confirmation that no dependencies exist from applications, analytics jobs, backups, or event streams; review of metadata (tags, names, creation dates) to establish purpose and ownership; validation with data owners regarding compliance or reference retention requirements.
misconfigurations.output_notes: DynamoDB charges apply continuously for storage (per GB-month) and read/write activity, making inactive tables a perpetual cost burden
misconfigurations.notes: CER ID: AWS-Databases-4839. Source: PointFive Hub

detection_methods.details: Monitor ConsumedReadCapacityUnits and ConsumedWriteCapacityUnits = 0 over extended period

misconfigurations.scenario: Inefficient Use of On-Demand Capacity in DynamoDB
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: DynamoDB tables using on-demand capacity mode with consistent, predictable traffic patterns that would benefit from provisioned capacity with auto-scaling
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Analyze traffic patterns over 2+ weeks, switch to provisioned capacity with auto-scaling for predictable workloads, maintain on-demand only for truly unpredictable or spiky workloads
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: On-demand capacity mode is convenient but costs approximately 6x more than provisioned capacity for steady-state workloads. Tables with predictable traffic patterns (consistent daily/weekly cycles) can significantly reduce costs by switching to provisioned capacity with auto-scaling. On-demand should be reserved for: new tables with unknown workload patterns, highly variable/spiky traffic, or development/test environments with sporadic usage.

misconfigurations.scenario: Suboptimal Storage Type for DynamoDB Table
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Tables with infrequently accessed data using Standard storage class, or tables with high-frequency access using Standard-IA
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable Standard-Infrequent Access (Standard-IA) table class for tables with infrequent access patterns, use Standard class for frequently accessed data
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: DynamoDB offers two table classes: Standard and Standard-Infrequent Access (Standard-IA). Standard-IA reduces storage costs by up to 60% but has higher read/write costs. Tables storing historical data, logs, or archives that are rarely accessed can benefit from Standard-IA. Analyze read/write patterns: if storage costs exceed throughput costs, Standard-IA is likely beneficial.
misconfigurations.output_notes: Standard-IA: 60% lower storage cost but higher throughput cost - ideal for storage-heavy, access-light workloads

misconfigurations.scenario: Underutilized Read Capacity on DynamoDB Table
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Provisioned read capacity units (RCUs) consistently underutilized (<30% utilization) over extended periods
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Reduce provisioned RCUs to match actual demand, enable auto-scaling with appropriate min/max bounds, consider switching to on-demand for highly variable workloads
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Over-provisioned read capacity wastes money on unused capacity. Tables with provisioned capacity should maintain 70-80% target utilization. If actual usage consistently falls below 30%, the table is significantly over-provisioned. Enable Application Auto Scaling to dynamically adjust capacity based on demand, or reduce provisioned capacity to match actual patterns.
misconfigurations.output_notes: Pay for provisioned capacity whether used or not; auto-scaling can optimize utilization

misconfigurations.scenario: Underutilized Write Capacity on DynamoDB Table
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Provisioned write capacity units (WCUs) consistently underutilized (<30% utilization) over extended periods
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Reduce provisioned WCUs to match actual demand, enable auto-scaling with appropriate min/max bounds, consider switching to on-demand for highly variable workloads
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Over-provisioned write capacity wastes money on unused capacity. Write capacity is approximately 5x more expensive than read capacity, making over-provisioning particularly costly. Tables with provisioned capacity should maintain 70-80% target utilization. Enable Application Auto Scaling to dynamically adjust capacity, or reduce provisioned capacity to match actual patterns.
misconfigurations.output_notes: Write capacity costs ~5x read capacity; over-provisioning is especially costly

misconfigurations.scenario: dynamo table read and write capacity is too low
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: lambda fails when trying to read dynamo taber; provisionedThroughputErrorException in logs' consumed read capacity is high, provisioned read capacity units are low
misconfigurations.notes: how do we determine what value to set as the read/write parameter? might be done automatically

misconfigurations.recommendation_action: implement kafka (or other) tool upstream to properly partition data prior to serving dynamodb
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: improper partitioning of dynamodb keys leading to excess capacity requirements; partitions (despite the aws documentation) do not happen linearly, thus upstream partitions are necessary

misconfigurations.scenario: user has the "hot key" problem (too many reads) with dynamo
user cannot predict the capacity needed with dynamo (RCUs / WCUs)
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: use on demand capacity (unlimited rcu & wcu)
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: on demand is 2.5x more expensive than provisioned capacity

misconfigurations.scenario: read latency is not performant for dynamodb tables OR user needs full replication (high reliability) of their dynamo tables
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: use global tables feature in dynamo db; NOTE dynamo db streams must be enabled

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to know whether they should cache read content (in a serverless architecture) at the api gateway level or with a DAX caching layer (or other)
